Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge was justified in conducting an oral hearing to assess language skills despite a passed written test
Application_Facts: Ms. Liu passed the written language test but displayed poor English during interaction; oral hearing conducted
Court_Ruling: The citizenship judge had jurisdiction and acted within legal authority
Defendant_Behavior: Conducted oral assessment of language proficiency
Legal_Standard: Adequate knowledge of one official language under the Citizenship Act
Applicable_Legislation: Citizenship Act, Subsection 5(1)(d); Citizenship Regulations, Section 14
Procedural_Issue: Legitimacy of oral hearing following written test passage
Credibility_Assessment: Judge concluded Ms. Liu lacked sufficient spoken English skills
Evidence_Used: Written test result, oral hearing performance
Legal_Provision_Cited: Subsection 5(1)(d), Citizenship Act; Section 14, Citizenship Regulations
Application_Basis: Failure to demonstrate adequate oral language proficiency
Governing_Rule: Language requirement for citizenship must be met through demonstrated proficiency
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of demonstrated oral English proficiency
Harm_Assessment: No harm found; decision within jurisdiction
Cause_Description: Ms. Liu's application for citizenship was denied due to insufficient English proficiency, leading to an appeal
Evidence_Handling: Oral hearing used to supplement written test
Evidence_Issues: Discrepancy between written test success and oral performance
Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether the judge had authority to conduct an oral hearing
Evidence_Assessment: Oral language skills assessed during hearing
Decision_Rationale: Judge had statutory authority to assess language orally and provided adequate reasons
Country_of_Origin: China (implied by name 'Liu', not explicitly stated)
Decision_Making_Body: Citizenship Judge, reviewed by Federal Court
Evidentiary_Issues: Reliance on oral assessment despite passing written test
Legal_Standard_Applied: Adequate knowledge of official language as per Citizenship Act
